Fax: +34 977557563. Graphical abstract New Cr(III) hexacoordinated complexes with tridentate NN′O-donor Schiff base ligands, M(NN′O)2Cl, have been prepared. They form active catalytic systems for the coupling of epoxides and carbon dioxide in the presence of co-catalysts. Best results were obtained with the complex with N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-3,5-di-tert-butyl-salicylaldimine (1) ligand and a co-catalyst. Cyclohexene oxide reacts with carbon dioxide in the presence of these catalysts to form mixtures of polycarbonate (PC) (productivity up to ca. 900g PC/g Cr) and cyclic carbonate depending on the co-catalyst and conditions employed. Cyclopentene, styrene and propylene oxides form selectively the cyclic carbonates at the conditions studied (epoxide conversion up to 97%). Although some of the co-catalysts are also active for the cycloaddition, the presence of both complex and co-catalyst has proved to be beneficial. Keywords Carbonates Carbon dioxide Catalysis Chromium Tridentate Schiff bases 1 Introduction Polycarbonates are polymeric materials with increasingly applications due to their properties such as extreme toughness and impact strength, high transparency, heat resistance, compatibility with other polymers, and biodegradability [1–4]. Their uses involve important areas such as the electrical and automotive sector, building and construction, optics, protection and packaging. The production of polycarbonates in 2011 was estimated in 605ktons [5]. Cyclic products also show wide applications. They are used as monomers for homopolymerization to polycarbonates but especially for copolymerization with cyclic esters leading to biodegradable materials for biomedical applications [6]. They are also used as polar aprotic solvents, antifoam additives or as plasticizers [3,7]. The industrial production of polycarbonates and cyclic carbonates is based in the (poly)condensation of a polyalcohol or an alcohol with phosgene [1], a highly toxic reagent (Scheme 1 a). An alternative and greener route to carbonates than the phosgene one, considers that the carbonate fragment can be directly obtained from carbon dioxide gas, provided that an efficient catalyst overcomes the energetic barrier due to the high inertness of this reactant [2,8,9]. For this alternative process, epoxides are very convenient starting materials since they are highly reactive due to the strain of the oxirane ring [3]. Furthermore, epoxides can be easily obtained by oxidation of accessible alkenes [10]. Since the initial discovery of Inoue's group that ZnEt2/H2O was an active catalytic system for the production of polycarbonates from CO2 and propylene oxide [11], a variety of catalysts have been developed for this transformation [2]. The best catalysts among Zn complexes are the ones containing β-diiminato ligands [12]. The advantage of using metal complexes is that not only the carbonate content is high, but also that stereoselective inducers (chiral ligands) can be introduced to obtain polymeric carbonates with optical properties. For example, Nozaki's group has developed a family of Zn-complexes with proline derivatives for the asymmetric copolymerization of CO2 with cyclohexene oxide affording 70% ee of chiral induction [13]. Metal complexes with salycylimine derivatives (salen) have also been successfully applied as catalysts for this transformation [14], usually in combination with a co-catalyst [15]. Different co-catalysts have been employed: N-heterocyclic amines, phosphines or anions derived from PPN+ (PPN+ =[Ph3P=N=PPh3]+) and ammonium salts [14b]. In the case of using N-heterocyclic amines, it was claimed that one hexacoordinated species formed by coordination of the amine in the axial position. Chromium complexes have proved to be among the most effective catalysts for polycarbonate synthesis [14]. They can be easily prepared from available Cr(II) acetate or chloride starting materials and they present high stability. Based on this background, we decided to prepare different chromium(III) complexes, which incorporate the axial co-catalyst as a fragment of the ligand. The potential advantage respect to metal–salen complexes would be that the co-catalyst would be incorporated in the catalyst. In the literature there are several reported catalytic systems including the co-catalyst attached as pendant arm [16]. Our approach was to use tridentate NN′O–donor ligands that, when coordinated, may form metal hexacoordinated species “M(NN′O)2” prone to be easily transformed into pentacoordinated systems. Flexible alkoxo–imino–amino ligands (1–6, Fig. 1 ) were selected for this purpose. The different amino groups studied include aromatic (pyridine, quinoleine), alkylic (–NMe2) and cyclic (pyrrolidine and pyperidine) functionalities. Calcium(II) and zinc(II) complexes with ligands 1, 3 and 4 were reported to be active in the ring opening polymerization of lactide [17]. We previously reported the synthesis of Mn(III) complexes with ligands 1 and 2 and their catalytic activity in the epoxidation of alkenes [18]. Here, chromium(III) complexes have been prepared and tested as catalyst in the coupling of carbon dioxide and different epoxides (cyclohexene, cyclooctene, cyclopentene, styrene and propylene oxides). 2 Experimental 2.1 General information Cyclohexene oxide, styrene oxide and propylene oxide were distilled over CaH2 and stored under nitrogen. Carbon dioxide (CO2, CP grade 5.3 and SCF Grade, 99.995%) was supplied by Air Products. Solvents were purified through distillation or purification system Braun MB SPS-800 and stored under nitrogen atmosphere. IR spectra (range 4000–400cm−1) were recorded on a Midac Grams/386 spectrometer in ATR or KBr. Conductivity was measured with a Crison conductimeter GLP equipped with a conductivity Pt cell. UV–vis spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-1203 spectrophotometer. MALDI-TOF measurements were performed on a Voyager-DE-STR (Applied Biosystems, Franingham, MA) instrument equipped with a 337nm nitrogen laser. All spectra were acquired in the positive ion reflector mode. Dithranol was used as matrix, which was dissolved in MeOH at a concentration of 10mgmL−1. The complex (1mg) was dissolved in 1mL of THF or CH2Cl2 and the polymer (5mg) was dissolved in 1mL of CHCl3. 1μL of sample, 1μL of matrix and 1μL of potassium trifluoroacetate (KTFA) solution in the case of polymers (1mg of KTFA in 1mL of THF) were deposited consecutively on the stainless steel sample holder and allowed to dry before introduction into the mass spectrometer. Three independent measurements were made for each sample. For each spectrum 100 laser shots were accumulated. Electrospray ionization mass spectra (ESI-MS) were obtained with an Agilent Technologies mass spectrometer. Typically, a dilute solution of the compound in DMF/methanol (1:99) was delivered directly to the spectrometer source at 0.01mLmin−1 with a Hamilton microsyringe controlled by a single-syringe infusion pump. The nebulizer tip operated at 3000–3500V and 250°C, and nitrogen was both the drying and a nebulizing gas. The cone voltage was 30V. Quasi-molecular ion peaks [M−H]− (negative ion mode) or sodiated [M+Na]+ (positive ion mode) peaks were assigned on the basis of the m/z values. Melting points (Mp) were measured on a Griffin melting point apparatus and are uncorrected. The molecular weights (M w) of copolymers and the molecular weight distributions (M w/M n) were determined by gel permeation chromatography versus polystyrene standards. Measurements were made in THF on a Millipore-Waters 510 HPLC Pump device using three-serial column system (MZ-Gel 100Å, MZ-Gel 1000Å, MZ-Gel 10,000Å linear columns) with UV-Detector (ERC-7215) and IR-Detector (ERC-7515a). The software used to get the data was NTeqGPC 5.1. Samples were prepared as follow: 10mg of the copolymer was dissolved with 2mL of tetrahydrofuran (HPLC grade) stabilized with 2,6-di-tert-4-methylphenol. Magnetic susceptibilities were measured on a Sherwood MSB mk1 magnetic susceptibility balance with KK105 calibration standard. 2.2 Ligand syntheses N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-3,5-di-tert-butyl-salicylaldimine (1), N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-2-hydroxy-3,5-di-tert-butyl-benzylamine (2) [21], N-(8-quinolyl)-3,5-di-tert-butyl-salicylaldimine [22] and N-(2-(dimethylamino)ethyl)-3,5-di-tert-butyl-salicylaldimine (4) [23] were prepared as previously reported. Novel N-(2-(pyrrolidino)ethyl)-3,5-di-tert-butyl-salicylaldimine (5) and N-(2-(piperidino)ethyl)-3,5-di-tert-butyl-salicylaldimine (6) were prepared by a similar method as the one reported for the analogous compounds with salicylaldehyde [24,25]. 2.3 Complex syntheses Synthesis of [Cr(1) 2 Cl] (Cr1). 1 (0.680g, 2.50mmol) was dissolved in 36mL of distilled and deoxygenated THF under inert atmosphere and CrCl2 (0.255g, 2.10mmol) was added to this solution. Structure solution was performed with SIR2011 [19] and structure refinement with SHELXTL V6.14 [20]. 2.4 Catalysis The catalytic tests were carried out in a 100mL Berghof reactor, which was previously kept under vacuum overnight at 100°C. After cooling, a solution under inert atmosphere containing the catalyst dissolved in net distilled substrate and the co-catalyst, when indicated, was injected into the reactor. The autoclave was pressurized with CO2, and then heated to 80°C to reach the desired pressure. After the reaction time, the reactor was cooled down and slowly depressurized. The % conversion was determined by 1H NMR of the crude mixture. The work-up was as follow depending on the substrate. Typical procedure for cyclohexene oxide: the final mixture was dissolved in dichloromethane, the solvent was evaporated and the residue dried in vacuum at 100°C for 3h to remove excess of cyclohexene oxide. The final residue was extracted several times with hexane to remove the cyclohexene carbonate and the residue contained the polymer. Both fractions were analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. The productivity in polymer was calculated from the mass of the isolated product-weight of the catalyst and co-catalyst [32]. % of CO2 content was calculated from 1H NMR data by the integral ratio between copolymer carbonate linkages (δ =4.65ppm) respect to ether linkage signals (δ =3.45ppm). % Z/E cyclic carbonate ratio was calculated from the integral ratio between the CH signals of the Z-isomer (δ =4.63ppm) and the E-isomer (δ =3.90ppm). Typical procedure for cyclooctene, cyclopentene, styrene and propylene oxides: the final crude mixture was analyzed by 1H NMR and the conversion was calculated by integral ratio between alkene oxide and cyclic carbonate. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of complexes Ligands 1–6 (Scheme 2 ) were prepared according to reported method from the literature by condensation of the salycil aldehyde derivative with the corresponding diamine [21–25]. Cr(III) compounds with 1–6 were prepared following procedures described in the literature for metal–salen complexes starting with CrCl2 and posterior oxidation with air to Cr(III) species Cr1–6 [26]. The infrared data of complexes Cr1–6 confirmed the coordination of the corresponding ligand. The stretching CN band was shifted to lower energy values, indicating coordination of the N imino group to the metal centre. For the Cr1–6 complexes, the variation of frequency values between free ligand and coordinated Δ ν ¯ ( ν ¯ ( C N ) Ligand − ν ¯ ( C N ) Complex ) ranged 6–27cm−1. Δ ν ¯ were higher when more basic amine fragments, such as dimethylamine (20cm−1, pKa=10.73) or pyrrolidine (27cm−1, pKa=11.31), were used, and lower for the quinoline derivative (6cm−1, pKa=4.90). The mass spectrometry data showed the presence of [Cr(1–6)2]+ species. Microanalysis results fit well with hydrated forms. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of the complexes at room temperature gave μ eff in the range corresponding to three unpaired electrons in an Oh symmetry (3.6–3.9 μ B) [27]. For Cr(III) complexes, the values of the molar conductivity (Λ M) in acetonitrile and dichloromethane solutions ranged from 0.31 to 37.5Scm2 mol−1, which are in the proposed interval for neutral complexes [28]. To fulfil this requirement, chloride must be coordinated to the metal centre. Therefore, the proposed structures are neutral hexacoordinated complexes [Cr(L–κ 3 N,N,O)(L -κ 2 N,O)Cl] in which one ligand is tridentate κ 3 N,N,O and the other acts as a bidentate κ 2 N,O. The electronic spectra of complexes Cr1, Cr3, Cr5 and Cr6 in acetonitrile and Cr2 and Cr4 in dichloromethane showed absorption bands in the region 519–619nm (ɛ =2–7×102) attributed to the d–d transition 4A2g → 4T2g [29]. According to literature data, the bands in the region 300–400nm (ɛ =2–9×103) are assignable to ligand transitions [29]. Those in the 400nm may possibly be due to π→π* transitions of the CN orbitals and benzene ring and those below 300nm to the phenolato group. The structure of Cr6 was elucidated by X-ray diffraction spectroscopy, confirming the hypothesis of the octahedral complex (see discussion below). The chloride in Cr1 was exchanged by the poor coordinating anion BArF− (B(C5H3-3,5-CF3)4 −) by reaction of Cr1 in dichloromethane with NaBArF, to produce the cationic complex [Cr(1)2][BArF] (Cr1B). The molar conductivity (93.6S×cm2 mol−1) and high resolution mass spectrum (m/z corresponding to [Cr(1)2]+) are indicative of the formation of a cationic species. The IR spectrum showed the presence of the coordinated ligand ( ν ¯ ( C N ) 1614cm−1) and the CF stretching bands of BArF− ( ν ¯ 1126cm−1). Although the solid was thoroughly washed with hexane to remove non-reacted NaBArF, some small amounts of this salt may possibly remain in the product giving non-accurate microanalysis data. 3.2 X-ray diffraction structure of complex Cr6 Suitable crystals for X-ray diffraction were grown by slow diffusion of hexane into a dichloromethane solution of the hydrochloride of Cr6 co-crystallysed with CH2Cl2 and 0.5 hexane. The structure is shown in Fig. 2 and the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table 2 . The Cr(III) atom presents a distorted octahedral geometry with a tridentate ligand 6-κ 3 N,N,O coordinated in mer disposition. A second ligand is coordinated as bidentate 6-κ 2 N,O through the imino and alkoxo donor atoms and there is a pendant non-coordinated pyrrolidine fragment. The chloro ligand occupies the sixth axial position. The two alkoxo O-donor fragments (O1 and O2) are in cis relative disposition and the two imine donor groups (N1 and N3) are in trans relative disposition. The maximum distortion to decrease repulsions in the octahedral environment can be detected at the angle between the Cr(III) centre and the imino (N3) and coordinated pyrrolidine (N4) fragments (N3Cr1N4 100.19°). Also the CrN4 (pyrrolidino) distance (2.298(3)Å) is longer than the CrN3 (imino) one (2.016(3)Å). The distances CrO (1.919(2)–1.923(2)Å) and CrN (imino) (2.081(3) and 2.016(3)Å) are in the range of the ones reported for similar fenolato–imino–amino complexes [29,30]. The CrN(amino) distances are longer than the CrN(imino) as expected. The complex contains two six-member rings nearly planar (CrOCCCN) and one five-member ring with envelop conformation (CrNCCN). A short distance N2⋯Cl1a (3.051Å) is indicative of H-bonding by formation of a pyrrolidinium moiety [29]. 3.3 Catalysis The catalytic activity of complexes Cr1–6 in the reaction of CO2 and cyclohexene, cyclooctene, cyclopentene, styrene and propylene oxides using several co-catalysts at different conditions was studied. 3.3.1 Reaction of CO2 and cyclic epoxides (cyclohexene, cyclooctene and cyclopentene oxides) We firstly analyzed the catalytic activity of the new chromium complexes Cr1–6 in the copolymerization of CO2 and cyclohexene oxide. We studied the effect of the catalyst, the co-catalyst and pressure, in the conversion and selectivity of the products detected: poly(cyclohexene carbonate) and cyclic cyclohexene carbonate. These products were identified by 1H NMR by comparison with reported data for the polymer [31] and the cyclic products, cis- [32] and trans-cyclohexene carbonate [33]. Initially, we studied the catalytic activity of Cr1–6 (0.12%) in the coupling of CO2 and cyclohexene oxide (CHO) in net substrate at reported conditions (80°C, 50bar) [15c]. Among these catalysts, only Cr1 showed activity (7% epoxide conversion) producing copolymer with 70% of carbonate content (entry 1, Table 3 ). The low productivity (128g copolymer/g Cr at 12h) is consistent with the observation that Cr(salen)X complexes are not active in the same reaction in the absence of a co-catalyst [34]. When using [Cr(salen)X] catalytic systems, it has been reported that the presence of strongly binding co-catalysts, led to more reactive MO bonds and favour the polymerization [14d, 35]. Also, in our case, the addition of a heterocyclic amine such as N-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP) as co-catalyst improved the epoxide conversion up to 58% producing also cyclic carbonate (CC) (49/51 PC/CC, entry 2, Table 3). The polymer was purified by thoroughly washing with hexane and was obtained in a productivity of 601g/g of Cr. Analysis by 1H NMR revealed a high content of carbonate linkages (95%) and the molecular weight was 4300Da. DMAP did not catalyze the CO2/CHO coupling at the same conditions (entry 3, Table 1). Catalytic system Cr2/DMAP produced a similar mixture of polycarbonate and cyclic carbonate but the productivity in the polycarbonate and the incorporation of carbonate linkages in the polymer was lower (48%, entry 4, Table 3). Cr3–6/DMAP catalysts produced very low conversion (entries 5–8, Table 3). Pyrrolidine and pyperidine systems, Cr5/DMAP and Cr6/DMAP provided polycabonate in low productivity and % of carbonate incorporation 79 and 62%, respectively (entries 7 and 8, Table 3). Coordinated chloride in Cr1 may be labile enough to act as an epoxide ring opening nucleophile by a concerted or bimetallic mechanism, as proposed for Cr(salen)X based catalysts [34]. However, the possibility to form stable bis(chelate) [Cr(NN′O)2]+ species renders the activity low and hinders the insertion of carbon dioxide. The less active systems Cr3–6 probably form more stable bis(chelate) complexes and avoid polymerization. The addition of an excess of the amine co-catalysts would compete with the formation of the bis(chelate) species and facilitate the polymerization, although short chains are formed (M w ≈4000). Moreover, cyclic carbonate is also obtained indicating a difficult access of the epoxide to the metallic centre. In fact, lowering the DMAP/Cr1 ratio from 8 to 5, increased the epoxide conversion, the productivity, selectivity towards the polycarbonate and the molecular weight (entry 9, Table 3). A decrease in the polymer employing high co-catalyst loadings was also reported when using Cr salen catalysts [34]. The selectivity of the reaction was strongly influenced by the use of other co-catalysts (entries 10–15, Table 3). High selectivity in polycarbonate and high productivity was achieved using pyridine as cocatalyst (entry 10, Table 3) to form polymers with M w 2800Da. Polycarbonate was also mainly formed with the Cr1/NEt3 system. In this case, oligomers of low molecular weight were obtained with low productivity (entry 12, Table 3). These results are in agreement with the ones reported for Cr(III) salen based catalysts [34]. Neither pyridine nor NEt3 are active as catalysts for this reaction (entries 11 and 13, Table 3). In contrast, Cr1/PPNCl, formed mainly the cyclic carbonate (entry 14, Table 3), isolated in 42% yield (Z/E ratio 9/1). PPNCl was active at the same conditions in the coupling of CO2/CHO producing exclusively the cyclic cis carbonate in 23% yield (entry 15, Table 3). The effect of CO2 pressure on the productivity of polycarbonate was examined with the catalytic system Cr1/DMAP (Fig. 3 ). Increasing the pressure up to 62bar increased the productivity. At higher pressures the productivity in polycarbonate decreased and cyclic carbonate was formed. Near total selectivity in cyclic carbonate was obtained at 110bar. The CO2 incorporation in the polycarbonate was not affected by the CO2 pressure as reported by Darensbourg and col. for [Cr(salen)N3] catalytic systems [36].This pressure dependence of the catalytic activity was attributed to a favourable CO2 insertion as pressure increased up to 34.5bar. Beyond this pressure and up to 55.2bar, the activity in the polycarbonate formation decreased and this was attributed to the dilution effect due to the increase in volume in the more CO2 reach epoxide/catalyst phase. The cationic catalyst Cr1B containing the fluorinated counter anion BArF− was designed to better solubilize the catalyst into a supercritical CO2 phase. A reference experiment using Cr1B/DMAP at 50bar and 80°C showed that it was less active than Cr1/DMAP (entry 16, Table 3). In absence of a co-catalyst, Cr1B polymerized CHO to polyether. This is in contrast with the observation reported for Cr–salenX complexes. At supercritical conditions (180bar of CO2, 80°C) using the catalytic system Cr1B/DMAP the epoxide conversion decreased to 38%. During the elimination of the epoxide process by heating the crude at 100°C the remaining unreacted cyclohexene oxide polymerized and only polyether and cyclohexylcarbonate were obtained (entry 17, Table 3). At this point, the coupling of other cyclic substrates such as 5- and 8-membered cyclic epoxides and CO2 was studied using the best catalytic system Cr1/DMAP (molar ratio=1/8). Cyclooctene oxide did not react at the optimized reaction conditions (80°C, 50bar) and the starting materials were recovered (entry 18, Table 3). It has been reported that such hindered substrates required higher temperature to react [37]; however, the reaction did not take place by increasing the temperature up to 120°C (entry 19, Table 3). In contrast, cyclopentene oxide reacted with carbon dioxide under the same optimized reaction conditions (80°C, 50bar) affording the cyclic carbonate exclusively with high conversion. No polycarbonate was detected by NMR (entry 20, Table 3). 3.3.2 Chain end groups determination by MALDI-TOF To determinate the chain end groups of the polycarbonates obtained, the MALDI-TOF mass spectra of the polymers resulting from experiment 2 (catalyst Cr1/DMAP), experiment 10 (catalyst Cr1/Py) and experiment 14 (catalyst Cr1/PPNCl) from Table 3 were analyzed (Fig. 4 ). They all present repeating units of 142 m/z. A common main distribution is observed in all three cases attributed to fragments presenting two Cl terminal groups and an ether linkage (a +K, in Fig. 5 , expected for n =12 Cl(C7H10O3)12C6H10OC6H10ClK, m/z 1993.81; found 1995–1997). According to literature, the two chloro end groups could be originated from a chain transfer process between two growing polymer chains. They may result from an initiating reaction involving a nucleophilic attack of the chloride ion to the oxirane ring [38]. The ether linkage may be originated by two consecutive epoxide insertions whether in the initiation or during the growing steps. Other common minor fragments present at m/z 1978–1980 may correspond to chains with Cl and OH terminal groups and an ether linkage (b +K, in Fig. 5; expected for n =12 Cl(C7H10O3)12C6H10OC6H10OHK, m/z 1975.84). Polymers obtained with Py and DMAP containing catalytic systems show also a minor peak at m/z 2014–2015 that may arise from the polycarbonate with Cl and OH terminal groups (c +K, in Fig. 5, expected for n =13 Cl(C7H10O3)13C6H10OHK, m/z 2019.83). The peak detected in the polymer obtained with Cr1/DMAP at m/z 2062.20 may correspond to the chain with two OH terminal groups and an ether linkage (d in Fig. 5, expected for n =13 HO(C7H10O3)13C6H10OC6H10OH m/z 2060.97). Peaks at m/z =1961–1964 may correspond to chains containing two OH terminal groups (e in Fig. 5, expected for n =13 HO(C7H10O3)13C6H10OH m/z 1962.90). Finally, the MALDI TOF spectrum of the polymer obtained with Cr1/PPNCl displays a peak at m/z 1943.18 that may correspond to a fragment containing a OH and cyclohexenyl termination groups (f in Fig. 5, expected for n =13 HO(C7H10O3)13C6H9 m/z 1944.89). In summary, the MALDI-TOF analysis of the poly(cyclohexene carbonate) formed with Cr1 catalyst employing DMAP, Py and PPNCl as co-catalysts, suggests that the initiation step involves the opening of the epoxide by a nucleophilic attack of the chloride. Combination of two growing chains and insertion of two consecutive epoxides may take place. The presence of OH terminal groups in different minor chains indicates the presence of water acting as termination and also initiation group. Consequently, the mechanism we proposed may involve the dissociation of the chloride ligand in complex Cr1, which may be substituted by the pyridine or DMAP co-catalysts or directly by the epoxide substrate (a and b in Scheme 3 ). Opening of the epoxide by the Cl− gives place to the alkoxo species, which may produce the cyclic carbonate by intramolecular attack (c in Scheme 3). Alternate insertion of epoxide and CO2 led to the polycarbonate growing chain (d in Scheme 3). As evidenced by the chain end group analysis, termination may occur by different pathways including combination of two growing chains or protonolysis of water. 3.3.3 Coupling CO2 and acyclic epoxides (styrene and propylene oxides) Styrene oxide and propylene oxide reacted with carbon dioxide at 80°C and 50bar using Cr1/co-catalyst as catalytic system producing the cyclic carbonates selectively. No polycarbonate was detected by NMR. In general, a synergetic interaction was observed using the combination Cr1/co-catalyst, since most of the conversions (Table 4 ) improved the catalytic activity of the individual catalysts. The best result for the coupling of styrene oxide and CO2 was obtained using Cr1/PPNCl (97% conversion, entry 7, Table 4). In addition, Cr1/PPNCl was very active in the coupling of CO2 and propylene oxide (entry 14, Table 4) but in this case the conversion was the same as the one obtained with PPNCl. 4 Conclusion New Cr(III) complexes with tridentate Schiff bases have been prepared. The X-ray analysis of the pyrrolidine derivative Cr6 revealed the formation of a hexacoordinated neutral complex with a tridentate and a bidentate ligands. The conductivity measurements of the Cr(III) complexes supported the proposal. The Cr(III) complexes in the presence of a co-catalyst formed active species for the coupling of CO2 and epoxides. Coupling of carbon dioxide and cyclohexene oxide formed mixtures of polycarbonate and cyclic carbonate, where the ratio depended on the co-catalyst used. Reaction of CO2 and styrene or propylene oxide produced selectively the cyclic carbonate with up to 97% conversion (for styrene oxide using PPNCl as co-catalyst). In most cases, the presence of the complex and co-catalyst was proved to be beneficial for the conversion. The MALDI-TOF analysis of the poly(cyclohexene carbonate) formed suggests that the initiation step involves the opening of the epoxide by nucleophilic attack of the chloride. The combination of two growing chains took place giving place to chains with two –Cl terminal groups. Insertion of two consecutive epoxides may also take place. The presence of OH terminal groups in different minor chains indicated the presence water acting as termination and/or initiation group. coredata.dc:description: New Cr(III) hexacoordinated complexes with tridentate NN′O-donor Schiff base ligands, M(NN′O)2Cl, have been prepared. They form active catalytic systems for the coupling of epoxides and carbon dioxide in the presence of co-catalysts. Best results were obtained with the complex with N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-3,5-di-tert-butyl-salicylaldimine (1) ligand and a co-catalyst. Cyclohexene oxide reacts with carbon dioxide in the presence of these catalysts to form mixtures of polycarbonate (PC) (productivity up to ca. 900g PC/g Cr) and cyclic carbonate depending on the co-catalyst and conditions employed. Cyclopentene, styrene and propylene oxides form selectively the cyclic carbonates at the conditions studied (epoxide conversion up to 97%). Although some of the co-catalysts are also active for the cycloaddition, the presence of both complex and co-catalyst has proved to be beneficial.
coredata.dc:title: Chromium complexes with tridentate NN′O Schiff base ligands as catalysts for the coupling of CO2 and epoxides
